qas.question: In Orthodox tradition, what comes next in precdence after The Theotokos in the order of the saints?
What are hymns to the Theotokos called in Orthodox tradition?
In the liturgical sequences of the Eastern Church, who is placed next in prominence after Christ?
What is Mary proclaimed to be in the Orthodox tradition?
What do the Orthodox believe Mary remained to be before and after she gave birth to Christ?
Who did Mary proclaim that she was?
What church did Mary give The Theotokia to?
Who does the Virgin Mary say that she takes precedence over?
What services did Mary perform in the Eastern Church?

context: Orthodox Christianity includes a large number of traditions regarding the Ever Virgin Mary, the Theotokos. The Orthodox believe that she was and remained <a4_0>a virgin<a4_0/> before and after Christ's birth. <a1_0>The Theotokia<a1_0/> (i.e., hymns to the Theotokos) are an essential part of the <b8_0>Divine Services<b8_0/> in <b6_0>the Eastern Church<b6_0/> and their positioning within the liturgical sequence effectively places <a2_0>the Theotokos<a2_0/> in the most prominent place after Christ. Within the Orthodox tradition, the order of the saints begins with: The Theotokos, <a0_0>Angels<a0_0/>, Prophets, Apostles, Fathers, Martyrs, etc. giving the Virgin Mary precedence over <b7_0>the angels<b7_0/>. She is also proclaimed as the <a3_0>"<b5_0>Lady of the Angels<b5_0/>"<a3_0/>.
